name: oxalic acid production | oxalic acid | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/24954/documentation

This dataset refers to the production of 1 kg oxalic acid from propylene through the propylene oxidation method, a two-step method developed by Rhône-Poulenc, in China. The dataset is based on the supplementary materials (Table S10, page S13) of the Wang et al (2020) publication. ;In the first step, propylene enters a solution of nitric acid in a reactor at 10 – 40 oC, where it is partially oxidized and subsequently converted to α-nitratolactic acid. The stoichiometric equation is the following: ;C3H6 + 3HNO3 -> C3H5O5N + 2NO + 2H2O;During the second step of the process, oxygen at 45 – 100 oC is used to treat the mixed and partially oxidized acid produced from the previous step, forming oxalic acid, which is crystallized and filtered. The overall efficiency of the process is claimed to be  nearly 90% and approximately all of the propylene is converted. The stoichiometric equation for the second step is the following: C3H5O5N + 5/2 O2 -> C2H2O4 + CO2 + HNO3 + H2O. ;The oxygen input was not originally present in the original source. However, due to the fact that is a direct input required for the oxidization, the oxygen amount has been calculated based on the 2nd stoichiometric equation. The amount (approximately 0.89 kg) has been increased by 5% in order to account for losses (standard procedure in chemical production datasets that are modelled in Ecoinvent).;Reference: Wang, L., Wang, P., Chen, W.-Q., Wang, Q.-Q., & Lu, H.-S. (2020). Environmental Impacts of Scandium Oxide Production from Rare Earths Tailings of Bayan Obo Mine. Journal of Cleaner Production, 122464. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2020.122464.

The activity starts with the oxidization of propylene.

The activity ends with the production of oxalic acid.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data are considered representative of current production practices.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Since China is the major producer of oxalic acid (representing 66.7% of the global production - Source: https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20110111006011/en/Research-Markets-Chinas-Oxalic-Acid-Industry-2010-2012), this dataset is assumed to be valid for this entire geography.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Due to lack of data for other production pathways of oxalic acid, this dataset is assumed to be valid for the entire country of China.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
This dataset is based on the supplementary materials (Table S10, page S13) of the following publication: Wang, L., Wang, P., Chen, W.-Q., Wang, Q.-Q., & Lu, H.-S. (2020). Environmental Impacts of Scandium Oxide Production from Rare Earths Tailings of Bayan Obo Mine. Journal of Cleaner Production, 122464. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2020.122464. Individual exchanges that were not present within the Ecoinvent database have been modelled with assuming proxies. Unit conversion has been performed to some exchanges to match the unit of the foreground data with the unit of the representative process of Ecoinvent. More detailed info is provided in the individual comment of each exchange. Infrastructural input (i.e chemical factory) has been introduced to take into account the type of infrastructure used in order to produce the oxalic acid. This infrastructural input was not present on the original dataset and is added in order to comply with the requirements of the Ecoinvent database. The authors of the publication, compiled the dataset for oxalic acid based on the following:
Chemical Technology: An Integral Textbook, 2013. Wiley-VCH. 1-888. ISBN: 3527304460. 

Hocking M.B., 2006. Handbook of Chemical Technology and Pollution Control, 3rd Edition. Academic Press. 1-799. ISBN: 9780120887965. 

Hocking M.B., 2012. Modern Chemical Technology and Emission Control. Springer. 1-460. ISBN: 9783642697753. 

Kirk-Othmer Chemical Technology and the Environment, 2007. Wiley. 1-1349. ISBN: 9780470105405. 
Moulijn, J.A., Makkee, M., Diepen, A.E.V., 2013. Chemical Process Technology. Wiley. 1-566. ISBN: 9781444320244. 

Murzin, D.Y., 2018. Chemical Product Technology. de Gruyter. 1-280. ISBN: 9783110475319. 
P.R.C. National Standard GB/T 1626-2008, 2008. Oxalic acid for industrial use. China National Standardiza-tion Management Committee. December 1st. 

Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry, 2005. Wiley. pp. 17624/28029. ISBN 9783527306732. 
Wang, Y.S., Yun, K., Cao, Y., Qiu, R.C., 2017. Research status and prospect of industrialized preparation of oxalic acid. Modern Chemical Industry. 37, 15-18 (in Chinese).

exchanges.description: This infrastructural input has been assumed for compliance with the Ecoinvent Guidelines and was not originally present in the publication, on which this dataset was based (Wang, L., Wang, P., Chen, W.-Q., Wang, Q.-Q., & Lu, H.-S. (2020). Environmental Impacts of Scandium Oxide Production from Rare Earths Tailings of Bayan Obo Mine. Journal of Cleaner Production, 122464. doi:10.1016/j.jclepro.2020.122464). Value has been taken from the dataset ''acetic acid production, product in 98% solution state, GLO'' from the Ecoinvent database version 3.6. The chemical factory is assumed to have an average output of 50'000 t/a and a lifespan of fifty years.

exchanges.description: The total amount of water that is produced as byproduct based on the 2-stage stoichiometric equations in general comment section is 0.60 kg per kg of oxalic acid produced, The amount of waster water reported is 2.99 kg (0.00299 m3). based on the following: (supplementary materials table S10, page S13 of the following publication: Wang, L., Wang, P., Chen, W.-Q., Wang, Q.-Q., & Lu, H.-S. (2020). Environmental Impacts of Scandium Oxide Production from Rare Earths Tailings of Bayan Obo Mine. Journal of Cleaner Production, 122464. doi:10.1016/j.jclepro.2020.122464). Therefore, for mass balance purposes an input of 0.00239 m3 (2.39 kg) is assumed here.

Amount taken from the supplementary materials table S10, page S13 of the following publication: Wang, L., Wang, P., Chen, W.-Q., Wang, Q.-Q., & Lu, H.-S. (2020). Environmental Impacts of Scandium Oxide Production from Rare Earths Tailings of Bayan Obo Mine. Journal of Cleaner Production, 122464. doi:10.1016/j.jclepro.2020.122464.

exchanges.description: The original amount is 0.89 kg and is based on the 2nd-stage stoichiometric equation for the production of oxalic acid (see general comment). This input was not present in the source, in which this dataset is based on (supplementary materials table S10, page S13 of the following publication: Wang, L., Wang, P., Chen, W.-Q., Wang, Q.-Q., & Lu, H.-S. (2020). Environmental Impacts of Scandium Oxide Production from Rare Earths Tailings of Bayan Obo Mine. Journal of Cleaner Production, 122464. doi:10.1016/j.jclepro.2020.122464). The value has been increased by 5% to take into account the losses from the production (which is what a standard procedure in chemical production datasets that are modelled in Ecoinvent).

exchanges.description: This exchange represents the amount of oxygen loss from the production of oxalic acid. The amount oxygen loss is assumed to be 5% of the original amount reported (check oxygen liquid exchange comment). This value was not contained in the originnal source, on which this dataset is based on (Source: Wang, L., Wang, P., Chen, W.-Q., Wang, Q.-Q., & Lu, H.-S. (2020). Environmental Impacts of Scandium Oxide Production from Rare Earths Tailings of Bayan Obo Mine. Journal of Cleaner Production, 122464. doi:10.1016/j.jclepro.2020.122464).

Proxy considered for the mother liquor that is produced as a byproduct (Source: http://eacharya.inflibnet.ac.in/data-server/eacharya-documents/55daa452e41301c73a2cb5ac_INFIEP_208/579/ET/208-579-ET-V1-S1__lecture_10_oxalic_acid.pdf). The value is calculated based on dry mass balance. This byproduct was not present in the source, in which this dataset is based on (supplementary materials table S10, page S13 of the following publication: Wang, L., Wang, P., Chen, W.-Q., Wang, Q.-Q., & Lu, H.-S. (2020). Environmental Impacts of Scandium Oxide Production from Rare Earths Tailings of Bayan Obo Mine. Journal of Cleaner Production, 122464. doi:10.1016/j.jclepro.2020.122464).

exchanges.description: This exchange represents the total thermal energy produced from steam.The original value reported is 0.66 m3  per kg of produced oxalic acid. The abovementioned value is taken from the supplementary materials (Table S10, page S13)  of the following publication: Wang, L., Wang, P., Chen, W.-Q., Wang, Q.-Q., & Lu, H.-S. (2020). Environmental Impacts of Scandium Oxide Production from Rare Earths Tailings of Bayan Obo Mine. Journal of Cleaner Production, 122464. doi:10.1016/j.jclepro.2020.122464. Based on the existing datasets of Ecoinvent for heat production through steam, the assumed energy content of steam is 2.75 MJ/kg. According to the Engineering toolbox, this value represents steam production between 500 °C and 550 °C, with densities of 2.67 kg/m3 and 2.92 kg/m3 respectively. An average density of 2.795 kg/m3 has been considered. Source: https://www.engineeringtoolbox.com/saturated-steam-properties-d_101.html. The calculated amount of energy is then multiplied by 1.31, in order to account for the heat loss associated with the production of steam. An activty link was set for this exchange, as the authors of the publication state that steam is produced from coal.

exchanges.description: This exchange represents the total thermal energy produced from coke.The original value reported is 0.51 kg per kg of of produced oxalic acid. The abovementioned value is taken from the supplementary materials of the following publication: Wang, L., Wang, P., Chen, W.-Q., Wang, Q.-Q., & Lu, H.-S. (2020). Environmental Impacts of Scandium Oxide Production from Rare Earths Tailings of Bayan Obo Mine. Journal of Cleaner Production, 122464. doi:10.1016/j.jclepro.2020.122464. The original amount was converted in MJ. Gross calorific value of coke: 28.9 MJ/kg (according to Ecoinvent data quality guidelines version 3, chapter 5.6.3, page 36. Source: http://www.fao.org/3/T0269e/t0269e0c.htm. An activty link was set for this exchange, to ensure that the supplied heat comes from coke.
